Graphical abstract The interfacial complexation of a natural organic acid with cobalt ions on graphene oxide sheets is proposed to manipulate the bridging structure of atomically dispersed cobalt and nitrogen atoms for improving bifunctional electrocatalysis in Zn-air batteries. Electrocatalysts with atomically dispersed metal moieties are of importance in enhancing electrocatalysis for a specific reaction including oxygen reduction. However, it is still challenging to modulate the coordination structure of metal atoms with heteroatoms on carbon supports. Herein, an innovative and facile bridging strategy to regulate the coordination structure of cobalt with nitrogen atoms on reduced graphene oxide (rGO) sheets was developed by the interfacial complexation of amino-rich folic acid with cobalt ions on graphene oxide sheets and the subsequent thermal treatment. Typically, the actual coordination interaction between cobalt and nitrogen species was revealed by using X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS), exhibiting the Co-N4 coordination structure well-dispersed on reduced graphene oxide. Such unique structure enables the efficient oxygen reduction and evolution reactions via the favorable adsorption and desorption of intermediates. With the enhanced bifunctional electrocatalytic activities, the fabricated Zn-air battery exhibited the excellent performance with large power density of 319.8 mW cm−2 and good long-term stability (over 300 h). This work establishes the synthesis strategy for bridging metal atom with heteroatom on graphene sheets to enhance the bifunctional electrocatalysis toward Zn-air batteries. Keywords Oxygen reduction reaction Synergistic effect Bifunctional electrocatalysis Bridging structure 1 Introduction Clean energy storage and conversion devices are indispensable to alleviate energy crisis and environmental issues. High performing rechargeable batteries (e.g., Zn-air batteries) are identified as the most promising alternatives of energy sources for portable electronic devices by virtues of good safety, sustainable and low cost [1–3]. For Zn-air batteries, the charge/discharge efficiency and cycling stability are still limited by the obstacle of the sluggish kinetics and multistep electron transfer process of oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and oxygen reduction reaction (ORR). In comparison with the high cost of noble metal electrocatalysts (i.e., Pt, RuO2) [4,5], the development of efficient bifunctional electrocatalysts via the rational atomic structure design and composition regulation is of great significance and highly attractive to improve the battery performance. To improve the electrocatalytic efficiency, the microstructure of metal active components is from the nanometer-scale down to sub-nanometer cluster and even single atoms [6]. The atomic dispersion of metal atoms on high conductive carbon support via the coordination effect provides efficient pathways to enhance their electrocatalytic activity toward electrochemical reactions including ORR and OER due to their highly atomic utilization efficiency and strong metal-support interaction [7–9]. For instance, single-atom nickel dispersed on nitrogen-doped carbons via an ionic exchange strategy manifested good electrocatalytic performance for electrochemical CO2 reduction [10]. The nitrogen and phosphorus co-doped carbon with atomically dispersed iron species provided the impressive ORR durability [11], whereas the cobalt single-atom sites dispersed carbon exhibited the desirable cycling stability [12–14]. To synthesize such electrocatalyst, the conventional impregnation/adsorption of metal ions and subsequent pyrolysis process commonly results in the uncontrollable agglomeration. Thus, it is a complex process to introduce high-content metal active sites and maintain them atomically dispersed simultaneously. The design of bridging structure is an efficient strategy in inhibiting the formation of metal agglomerate during pyrolysis, which would be able to establish the favourable interplay between metal atoms with heteroatoms on the conductive carbon support [15]. Folic acid (vitamin B9, FA) is a bioactive component related to a variety of health problems. It has been revealed that the presence of metal ions (i.e., Ca2+, Cu2+ and Zn2+) would change the biomolecular interaction between FA and protein (e.g., bovine serum albumin) [16]. Therefore, we modulated the interaction of cobalt ions and graphene oxide (GO) by introducing folic acid as bridging agent and achieved single-atom cobalt N-doped graphene (denoted as AT-Co/NDG) via the pyrolysis process (Scheme 1 ). Notably, the presence of folic acid not only endows the well-dispersion of cobalt ions on graphene oxide sheets due to the strong complexation capacity, but also provides abundant nitrogen containing functional groups for optimizing the bridging structure with nitrogen doping under thermal treatment. The actual coordination structure of cobalt with nitrogen atoms on rGO sheet was revealed by X-ray absorption fine structure spectroscopy. With the boosted electrocatalytic performance for oxygen reduction and evolution reactions, the optimized AT-Co/NDG was employed to fabricate high-performing Zn-air batteries, showing larger power density and outstanding long-time stability. 2 Experimental 2.1 Sample preparation GO was synthesized by graphite flake according to our previous work [17]. In detail, GO solution (60 mL, 0.5 mg mL−1) was dispersed uniformly and 5 mL folic acid (FA, 220.7 mg) aqueous solution was added 84 mg of NaHCO3 to form FA solution. With addition of FA, GO dispersion transformed into colloidal state. Next, CoCl2 solution (95.2 mg, 10 mL) was dropped into the GO-FA mixed solution under stirring. The stable and finely-dispersed mixture was rapidly frozen in liquid nitrogen, and further dried by lyophilization. For the preparation of AT-Co/NDG samples, the obtained precursor was pyrolyzed under flow N2 at desired temperatures (700, 800 and 900 °C) for 1 h to obtain the samples (Co NPs/NG-7, Co NPs/NG, and Co NPs/NG-9). Then, the samples were etched with 1 M HCl at 80 °C water bath and washed with ultrapure water several times. The Co NPs/NG was activated under the same conditions to obtain AT-Co/NDG sample. For comparison, the control sample was also prepared via the same calcination process with absence of CoCl2 and named as NG. 2.2 Electrochemical characterization The electrochemical tests were carried out in a standard three-electrode system via a CHI 760E electrochemical workstation (CH Instrument, Shanghai) at ambient conditions. The glassy carbon (GC) electrode and Ag/AgCl electrode were served as the working and reference electrodes, respectively. A graphite rod employed as the counter electrode. The catalyst ink was prepared by blending 5 mg of the as-prepared catalysts with 1 mL ethanol solution ( V H 2 O : V C 2 H 2 O H = 3:1). Then, 10 μL catalyst ink and 5 μL Nafion solution (0.5 wt%, DuPont) successively were dispersed onto the surface of glassy carbon electrode with a mass loading of 0.21 mg cm−2. For comparison, the Pt/C (20 wt%, Sigma) electrode was prepared via same process, and the mass loading is 0.17 mg cm−2. All the potentials were calibrated to reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) based on the following formula: E RHE = E Ag/AgCl + 0.197 + 0.0591pH. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) and linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) measurements were performed by rotating ring-disk electrode (RRDE) in N2 or O2 saturated 0.1 M KOH electrolyte. For the in-situ Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy measurements, diamond crystal was acted as the infrared transmission window, whose infrared spectroscopy range can broad to 800–4000 cm−1. The detector is a liquid-nitrogen-cooled MCT detector and a high spectral resolution of 2 cm−1 was used. 10 μL catalyst ink (30 mg mL−1) was dripped onto the diamond crystal and the thin film was uniformly formed at room temperature, which might alleviate the loss of infrared light. The tests were in a home-made electrochemical cell equipped with the flowing O2-saturated 0.1 M KOH electrolyte. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Microstructure and composition analysis GO nanosheets are easily aggregated to precipitates in the presence of cobalt ions due to the electrostatic interaction. Thus, it is attractive to anchor cobalt species with the help of a suitable bridging agent and tackle the re-stacking issue of GO sheets. In this regard, folic acid with nitrogen and oxygen containing groups would afford available sites to trap metal species on graphene oxide surface in order to avoid the aggregation. Therefore, the anchoring of desirable cobalt species on the nitrogen doped rGO sheets could be achieved in the presence of folic acid via the thermal treatment and subsequent activation process (Scheme 1). The microstructure and microtopography of Co NPs/NG and AT-Co/NDG were examined by using scanning electron microscopy (SEM). A few of nanoparticles (ca. 130 nm) were dispersed on the two-dimensional rGO sheets (Fig. S1a, b, and d). The energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) coupled with elemental mapping images manifest the uniform distribution of C, N, O throughout rGO sheet with the strong signal response of the metal Co for the particles (Fig. S1c and e). It indicates that the folic acid was decomposed into nitrogen component during carbonization process, at the same time, the cobalt species that are not anchored are prefer to form cobalt nanoparticles. For the AT-Co/NDG samples, Fig. 1 (a) depicts crumpled reduced graphene oxide sheets with lots of wrinkles, and no obvious nanoparticles are observed, which is accordant to the enlarged transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images (Fig. 1b). Notably, a few of large holes are observed on the rGO sheets due to the thermal etching and the subsequently removing of Co nanoparticles, which would expose more active sites around rGO edges. As shown in Fig. 1(c), the characteristic X-ray diffraction (XRD) peaks of Co NPs/NG samples at round 44.2°, 51.5° and 75.9° are corresponding to the (111), (200), and (220) lattice planes of Face-Centered Cubic (FCC) cobalt crystal structure (JCPDS NO.15-0806). In contrast, for the AT-Co/NDG sample, no diffraction peaks about cobalt species are observed in addition to the broad carbon peak at around 26°. The results suggest that the metallic cobalt would be able to be completely dissolved during the acid washing process. However, the elemental mapping images of the AT-Co/NDG catalyst (Fig. 1d) exhibit the uniform dispersion of Co, N, C and O elements and the inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) confirms the presence of cobalt species with a content of around 1.7 wt% [18]. Thus, cobalt species would be atomically dispersed on the nitrogen-doped rGO sheet in AT-Co/NDG sample. To demonstrate the key role of folic acid and further understand the possible interaction mechanism, the control experiment was performed by using the identical procedure in the absence of folic acid (Fig. 2 ). When cobalt ions are adsorbed on the surface of GO via the electrostatic interaction, the TEM image shows that cobalt nanoparticles went through irregular agglomeration after thermal treatment (Fig. S2a). Furthermore, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and ICP-MS results reveal the presence of C and O elements but no cobalt species left after the acid washing process, suggesting the completely elimination of Co moieties (Fig. S2b). In contrast, in the presence of folic acid, cobalt ions can be trapped with amino groups due to complexation interactions. Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectrum was performed to further analyze functional groups of the FA-Co-GO precursor, unanimously corroborating the strong interaction between Co2+ ions and the amino groups. As displayed in Fig. 3 (a), FTIR spectrum exhibits the characteristic absorption peaks of pure folic acid at 3543, 3416, 1694, 1606, 1484 and 923 cm−1. Notably, bimodal absorption peaks between 3500 and 3300 cm−1 are attributed to –NH2 bands stretching vibrations, whereas the absorption peaks located at 1694 cm−1 represents CO stretching vibration of carboxyl groups as well as 1606 cm−1 peaks is assigned to N–H bands bending vibration [19]. It has been revealed that folic acid possesses enriched nucleophilic functional groups to chelate with various metal ions [20]. The blue shift of N–H amide-II (1597 cm−1) bending vibration peaks to a high wavenumber of 1609 cm−1 evidenced the presence of a chemical interaction between FA-Co and GO [21,22]. These above results confirm the role of folic acid as bridging agent between metal ions and conductive carbon substrate. During the pyrolysis process, the carbonization of folic acid molecules would provide the nitrogen sources for anchoring atomically dispersed cobalt species on rGO sheets via the coordination to form Co–N x moieties. However, the excessive cobalt would migrate and aggregate into large isolated nanoparticles. These cobalt nanoparticles would facilitate the decomposition of carbon around the particles due to the catalysis of such metal species [23]. Thus, the large holes are formed after acid washing. Especially, the coordination of cobalt with nitrogen around the holes would provide active sites for improving the electrocatalytic activity. These large holes enable the rapid mass transfer, and thus enhancing reactive kinetics. To further investigate defects around the edge region of rGO holes, the Raman spectra of AT-Co/NDG and Co NPs/NG samples were presented in Fig. 3(b). It can be observed that D and G band peaks are located at 1350 and 1600 cm−1 in both AT-Co/NDG and Co NPs/NG catalysts, respectively. As described in Fig. 3(c), the Raman spectra confirms that the AT-Co/NDG catalyst can be deconvolved into four peaks, namely, disorder D1 band (edge plane defects), graphitic G band (sp 2-C), amorphous D3 band, and D4 band (ionic impurities or polyene-like structures) [24]. The enhanced I D1/I G (intensity ratio) commonly suggests the increase of the structural disorder among the carbon materials. The I D1/I G ratio of AT-Co/NDG was 1.98, higher than that of Co NPs/NG (1.08, Fig. S6). The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) specific surface area of AT-Co/NDG is 325.3 m2 g−1, which would expose more defect sites around rGO edges for improving electrocatalytic activity (Fig. S7) [25]. The elemental valence state and composition of as-prepared samples were further qualitatively analyzed by XPS characterization. The survey spectroscopy of AT-Co/NDG manifests the existence of C, O, N, and Co moieties (Fig. S8). As presented in Fig. S9, the high-resolution C 1s spectra could be fitted into four peaks. The presence of C–N peak at 285.6 eV suggests the successful doping of nitrogen into carbon scaffold (Table S1) [26,27]. As depicted in Fig. 3(d), the positive shift to 399.3 eV in comparison with pyridinic-N (398.4 eV) is observed in AT-Co/NDG sample but not in NG sample, which would be attributed to the binding of pyridinic N with cobalt moiety (e.g., Co–N x ) [28,29]. The content of Co–N x constituents is around 11.0%, whereas pyridinic-N (398.4 eV) and graphitic-N (401 eV) contents are 30.9% and 33.1%, respectively (Fig. 3e). The Co 2p high-resolution XPS spectra reveal that no metallic Co signal is presence in AT-Co/NDG. The Co 2p 3/2 dominant peak with a binding energy of 780.4 eV is located between those of Co0 (779.6 eV) and Co2+ (781.4 eV), suggesting positively charged nature of Co atoms in AT-Co/NDG (Fig. 3f) [30]. The higher Co valence state in AT-Co/NDG would be attributed to the formation of coordination structure with nitrogen. To finely investigate the electronic structure, soft X-ray absorption near edge spectroscopy (XANES) of C K-edge and N K-edge measurements were performed on AT-Co/NDG and Co NPs/NG samples. As shown in Fig. 4 (a and b), the π* peaks at 286.6 and 399.2 eV for normalized C and N K-edge spectra, respectively, suggest the presence of C–N–C species. The characteristic intensity increasing in C K-edge but decreasing in N K-edge spectra for AT-Co/NDG sample explicitly illustrate a charge redistribution [31,32]. The chemical valence state along with coordination structure of cobalt atoms in AT-Co/NDG sample was investigated by using X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS) spectroscopy. As displayed in Fig. 4(c), the rising pre-edge of AT-Co/NDG is located between those of the standard Co foil and Co3O4. Thus, the valence state of cobalt in AT-Co/NDG is between Co (0) and Co (Ⅱ/III), which is in good agreement with the XPS results, indicating a porphyrinic planar structure for single-atom cobalt sites [30]. Fourier-transformed (FT) k 3-weighted extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) spectra is further used to analyze the structure information. A single prominent peak at around 1.35 Å for AT-Co/NDG is ascribed to the Co–N first scattering path [33]. Especially, no metallic Co or Co compounds was observed in AT-Co/NDG due to the absence of peaks at 2.16 Å for Co–Co coordination and other high-shell peak, demonstrating the formation of atomically dispersed Co atoms. Thus, it is unambiguous that the complexation of folic acid with cobalt ions facilitates the atomic dispersion during pyrolysis by restricting nanoparticles’ agglomeration, and thus enhances the active site density. The coordination number of Co–N first scattering path for AT-Co/NDG is ∼4.0 according to the fitting results of EXAFS (Table S2 & Fig. 4e). The Wavelet transform (WT) plots based on Morlet wavelets could vividly reflect the information of coordination type and bonding distance. In comparison to the contribution of Co–Co bond at 8.0 Å−1, the maximal intensity at circa 5.0 Å−1 for AT-Co/NDG further reveals the presence of Co-N coordination (Fig. 4f). Clearly, the experimental results demonstrate the formation of Co-N4 coordination model in the AT-Co/NDG catalyst. 3.2 Bifunctional electrocatalytic performance characterization of different catalysts The electrocatalytic performance of AT-Co/NDG is further investigated using standard three-electrodes system in 0.1 M KOH. As depicted in Fig. 5 (a), the obvious reduction peak is observed in oxygen-saturated electrolyte, but not in the electrolyte saturated with nitrogen, implying the ORR electrocatalytic reactivity for AT-Co/NDG catalysts. Moreover, the reduction peak potentials of AT-Co/NDG electrode is more positive in comparison with AT-Co/NDG-7 and AT-Co/NDG-9, suggesting the better electrocatalytic activity. From the RDE polarization plots, the half-wave potential (E 1/2) of AT-Co/NDG is 0.86 V vs. RHE, overtopping commercial Pt/C more than 30 mV. This is comparable to or even better many of the transition metal-based electrocatalysts reported recently in 0.1 M KOH medium (Fig. 5b and Table S3). The electron transferred number (n) and the hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) yield were obtained from the rotation ring-disk electrode (RRDE) measurement results. As shown in Fig. 5(c), the n values for AT-Co/NDG are in the range of 3.92 to 3.97, and the yield of H2O2 is lower than 5% during 0.2 to 0.8 V vs. RHE. The reuslts are comparable to those of Pt/C catalyst (3.88–3.94), suggesting that AT-Co/NDG sample enable oxygen be reduced via a direct four-electron pathway. The AT-Co/NDG catalyst shows a higher kinetic current density (J k @ 0.85 V vs. RHE) of 6.24 mA cm−2 and the lower Tafel slope of 63 mV dec−1, implying the favorable ORR reaction kinetics (Fig. S11). The accelerated durability test (ADT) was performed to verify the ORR stability of AT-Co/NDG. As shown in Fig. S12, the ORR polarization curves do not exhibit obvious degradation after 2000 cycles, suggesting good durability of AT-Co/NDG catalysts in alkaline medium. Simultaneously, the fuel cross-over effect of AT-Co/NDG and Pt/C catalysts was conducted using chronoamperometric current–time tests. As manifested in Fig. S13, no obvious current variation at the AT-Co/NDG electrode is observed after adding 3 mL methanol at 1000 s, whereas that of Pt/C curve drops suddenly. The robust resistance to the cross-over effect of methanol manifests the good selectivity of the AT-Co/NDG to ORR. In addition, the electrochemical specific surface area of AT-Co/NDG was examined by CV measurement in the potential region of 0.96–1.16 V at various scan rates (Fig. S14). The calculated double-layer capacitance of AT-Co/NDG is up to 78.5 mF cm−2, suggesting the large surface area. Particularly, the strong interaction between the reduced graphene oxide and the well-dispersed Co-N4 sites would optimize the electronic structure for improving the electrocatalytic performance [34]. Thus, the AT-Co/NDG electrocatalyst with atomically dispersed active sites exhibits good electrochemical performance. To clarify the electrocatalytic nature, the poisoning experiment with SCN− ions was performed. It has been revealed that the strong coordination ability of SCN− ions with metal active sites would block the active sites and thus inhabit oxygen reduction [35]. As shown in Fig. 5(d) and Fig. S16, in the presence of 10 mM KSCN electrolyte, the half-wave potential exhibits the obvious negative shift due to the shielding effect of SCN−. Therefore, the atomically dispersed Co atoms within AT-Co/NDG served as the main active sites for ORR. According to the ORR mechanism at single-atom transition metal active site (e.g., Ni-N4) proposed previously [36], the favorable adsorption and subsequent dissociation of O2 into the typical adsorbed intermediate, O* would leads to the highly efficient oxygen reduction via a 4e− process. Thus, the in-situ FTIR measurements were performed to examine the potential intermediates at Co single atom sites during oxygen reduction. Oxygen reduction process is commonly proposed via oxygen associative mechanism with multiple intermediates adsorbed (e.g., OOH*, O*, OH*. * denotes the reaction site.) [37]. As displayed in Fig. 5(e), an obvious absorption peak for the AT-Co/NDG is observed at 916 cm−1 with decreasing potential from 1.0 to 0.2 V. Given the position of single-oxygen/metal (O/M) stretching vibration peaks is situated at ∼900 cm−1, thus such absorption peak would be attributed to Co–O* species with the formation of O* intermediate during ORR process [36,38]. The results imply that the bridging structure of cobalt with nitrogen atoms on rGO could facilitate the adsorption and dissociation of surface O2 for the favorable four-electron ORR. Interestingly, AT-Co/NDG catalyst also demonstrates ORR activity in acidic media (Fig. S17). Although its half-wave potential is still negative to the commercial Pt/C catalyst, the ORR performance can come up to those of the non-noble metal catalysts reported [39]. The OER performance of as-prepared samples was investigated by LSV curves in 1.0 M KOH. As shown in Fig. 6 (a), it can be found that the AT-Co/NDG electrode exhibits the lowest potential of 1.54 V (vs. RHE) at 10 mA cm−2 than those of AT-Co/NDG-7 (1.64 V), AT-Co/NDG-9 (1.68 V), and RuO2 (1.60 V) catalysts. Additionally, the relatively smaller Tafel slope (137 mV dec−1) for AT-Co/NDG electrocatalyst in Fig. 6(b) suggests the favorable reaction kinetics process, in comparison with those of AT-Co/NDG-7 (174 mV dec−1) and AT-Co/NDG-9 (173 mV dec−1). The RRDE measurements was carried out in Fig. 6(c) to evaluate the OER reaction mechanism. With the increasing current density on the disk electrode, the low ring current density indicates the efficient reduction of oxygen with the formation of negligible peroxide species [40]. In addition, the Nyquist plots of electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) at AT-Co/NDG electrode illustrate a small charge-transfer resistance (R ct, 5.2 Ω) in comparison with AT-Co/NDG-7 (8.0 Ω) and AT-Co/NDG-9 (19.1 Ω), suggesting rapid ions exchange and favorable charge-transfer kinetics at AT-Co/NDG electrode interface (Fig. 6d) [41]. The bifunctional electrocatalytic performance was further investigated by examining the potential gap (ΔE) between OER (Ej =10) and ORR (E 1/2) at the 10 mA cm−2 current density for OER and the half-wave potential of ORR. The smaller ΔE value represents superior electrocatalytic performance and reversibility. As demonstrated in Fig. 6(e and f), AT-Co/NDG shows the smallest value of ΔE (0.79 V) than that of Pt/C-RuO2 catalyst (0.87 V), indicating the remarkable bifunctional activity. The enhanced bifunctional electrocatalysis would be contributed to the unique structural and composition features of AT-Co/NDG: (1) Atomically dispersed Co-N4 sites is available for the adsorption/desorption of oxygen intermediates species to obtain highly kinetic reactivity; (2) the unique porous structure of rGO network would provide rapid electron transfer pathways along with favorable mass transfer process of electrolyte and reactants; (3) the coordination between N and Co atoms would promote the electronic interaction for boosting ORR. 3.3 Zn-air batteries performance tests of different electrocatalysts Efficient bifunctional electrocatalysts are the crucial and obligatory component in the good operation of Zn-air batteries. To this end, we assembled Zn-air battery with carbon paper loaded AT-Co/NDG catalyst as air cathode as well as zinc foil as anode (Fig. 7 a). The AT-Co/NDG electrocatalyst assembled Zn-air battery displays a higher power density of 319.8 mW cm−2 than that of AT-Co/NDG-7 (195.3 mW cm−2), AT-Co/NDG-9 (161.4 mW cm−2) and Pt/C-RuO2 (99.7 mW cm−2), surpassing most of non-noble metal catalysts reported (Fig. 7b and Table S4). By the contact angle measurement, AT-Co/NDG catalysts are superior hydrophilic with the contact angle of 18.7°, suggesting the better wettability to electrolyte and a positive effect for performance (Fig. S19). To gain in-depth information of zinc utilization, the quantitative analysis of discharging capacities was performed. For AT-Co/NDG battery, the specific capacity is up to 746.4 mAh gZn −1 at current density of 50 mA cm−2 (normalized to the consumed Zn), corresponding to a specific energy density of 783.7 Wh kgZn −1 (Fig. 7c). Additionally, the AT-Co/NDG cathode exhibits a larger specific capacity of 800.9 mAh gZn −1 at 10 mA cm−2, close to the theoretical capacity of Zn-air batteries (820 mAh gZn −1) [42], which is superior to those of other batteries (AT-Co/NDG-7 ∼ 745.4 mAh gZn −1, AT-Co/NDG-9 ∼ 751.4 mAh gZn −1, and Pt/C-RuO2 catalyst ∼713.4 mAh gZn −1) (Fig. 7d). Such high utilization of metallic zinc in the Zn-air battery would benefit from good electrocatalytic activities of as-prepared electrocatalysts. To investigate the rate capability and long-term cycling stability of Zn-air batteries, we conducted a series of galvanostatic tests. After discharging at a large current density (50.0 mA cm−2), the AT-Co/NDG-based Zn-air battery still exhibit the superior reversibility with the quick recovery of discharge voltage to 1.26 V with a high voltage retention of 99.1% at 5 mA cm−2 (Fig. 7e). Most importantly, the AT-Co/NDG battery could be charged and discharged stably for more than 333 h. The cycling stability is significantly better than those of AT-Co/NDG-7, AT-Co/NDG-9 and Pt/C-RuO2 electrocatalysts batteries (Fig. 7f). The round-trip energy efficiency of AT-Co/NDG-based battery is up to 57.5 and 51.9% at 90 and 1000th cycle, respectively (Fig. 7g). The decrease of the electrolyte conductivity due to the possible reaction with carbon dioxide at ambient conditions would result in the slight stability decay [43]. Notably, when the current density increased to 10 mA cm−2, the round-trip efficiency still maintains 56% for AT-Co/NDG electrocatalyst battery (Fig. 7h), suggesting the robust long-term cycling stability. These results reveal that AT-Co/NDG samples possess an excellent performance in both three-electrode system and realistic Zn-air battery, providing an alternative for the next generation of energy applications. To satisfy the requirements of solid batteries, the sandwich plate structure solid-state Zn-air batteries were assembled (Fig. 8 a) [44]. A solid Zn-air battery could power a temperature/humidity display device, implying the promising application potential (Fig. 8b). Especially, AT-Co/NDG cathod possess a maximum power density value with 80 mW cm−2, which is 1.26 times than that of Pt/C-RuO2 battery (63.4 mW cm−2) (Fig. 8c). Additionally, the specific capacity of AT-Co/NDG demonstrate a visible superiority with 710.9 mAh gZn −1, superior to Pt/C-RuO2 (640.1 mAh gZn −1), manifesting its high energy efficiency (Fig. 8d). As depicted in Fig. 8(e), the AT-Co/NDG manifests a relatively higher discharging voltage compared to other samples in the galvanostatic rate performance tests, which might be attributed to the synergic effects of defective macro-porous rGO and atomically dispersed cobalt active sites. Importantly, the AT-Co/NDG-based solid-state Zn-air battery shows a long-term stability of 60 h at 2.0 mA cm−2 current density (Fig. 8f), implying the graphene supported Co-N4 sites catalysts could be promising alternatives for practical applications in portable device. 4 Conclusions To enhance the electrocatalytic activities of carbon-based electrocatalysts, we demonstrate a facile strategy to modulate the bridging structure of metal atoms with heteroatoms on rGO with the assistance of the complexation effect of folic acid with cobalt ions on graphene oxide sheets. The presence of folic acid is crucial to anchor active sites with cobalt species during the thermal treatment. Typically, the XANES and XPS results reveal the real coordination structure of cobalt with nitrogen atoms on rGO sheets. These active sites with the strong electronic interaction of cobalt and nitrogen on the conductive carbon support thus boost electrocatalytic activities and battery performance. Notably, the aqueous rechargeable Zn-air batteries show the largest power density of 319.8 mW cm−2 and an ultrahigh specific capability of 800.9 mAh gZn −1. Furthermore, the solid-state Zn-air batteries also exhibit a good long-term stability of 60 h. Thus, the regulation of atomic coordination structure of metal atoms with nitrogen on holey graphene matrix is efficient to enhance the good bifunctional catalytic activity, which offers a new choice for the ingenious design of advanced electrocatalysts. coredata.dc:description: Electrocatalysts with atomically dispersed metal moieties are of importance in enhancing electrocatalysis for a specific reaction including oxygen reduction. However, it is still challenging to modulate the coordination structure of metal atoms with heteroatoms on carbon supports. Herein, an innovative and facile bridging strategy to regulate the coordination structure of cobalt with nitrogen atoms on reduced graphene oxide (rGO) sheets was developed by the interfacial complexation of amino-rich folic acid with cobalt ions on graphene oxide sheets and the subsequent thermal treatment. Typically, the actual coordination interaction between cobalt and nitrogen species was revealed by using X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS), exhibiting the Co-N4 coordination structure well-dispersed on reduced graphene oxide. Such unique structure enables the efficient oxygen reduction and evolution reactions via the favorable adsorption and desorption of intermediates. With the enhanced bifunctional electrocatalytic activities, the fabricated Zn-air battery exhibited the excellent performance with large power density of 319.8 mW cm−2 and good long-term stability (over 300 h). This work establishes the synthesis strategy for bridging metal atom with heteroatom on graphene sheets to enhance the bifunctional electrocatalysis toward Zn-air batteries.
